text: [SLOW MUSIC PLAYING]

IGNACIO LARTIRIGOYEN:
I was raised
in a rural town in Argentina.

So I spent a lot of time
playing outside the house

and spending all
the day in the farm.

ERIN KAIVAN: I went to about
a high school of 120 people.

Maybe 20 of my graduating
class went to college.

Like, the Ivy League's
always seemed out of reach.

As far back as our
collective memory can go,

someone in my family has
served in the military

and that really inspired
me to pursue the same path.

MELCOLM RUFFIN: We grew up
on the west side of Chicago,
and we didn't have a lot.

But there was a lot of
love within my family.

I was the sports junkie, but
I knew every player's stats,

and so that was my
way of kind of being

a part of the
grown-up conversation.

ASPA LEKKA: I come from a city
in the northwest of Greece.
My hometown has great baklava.
It's famous for the baklava.
I love the piano.

I've been playing the
piano since I was six,

and then I started being
involved with handball.

[INAUDIBLE] I've
always in my life

had these moments of
feeling I should quit.

I had it also for piano, and
I had it also for handball.

And it's moments where it
becomes very challenging.

And I would probably
go back after a week

and start again and be,
OK, Aspa, now you're calm,
so you can start over again.

JULIO CEDENO: I grew up
in Houston my whole life.

Education was always
the number-one priority
in my house.

Math was always my
strong point, and then
I really enjoyed physics.

So I actually went
into college just--

those are my two
favorite subjects.
I'll just take math and physics.

Those classes were
a lot harder than I
realized they were going to be.

Thankfully, I kind of fell
into electrical engineering.

BRANDON LOVELL: I went to high
school in the South Bronx.

Going through high school, I
looked at it as more mandatory.

I didn't really
find a path for me

to really get out
of my neighborhood.

My grandfather always
championed me to kind of take
that extra step.
Hey, Brandon, you can do this.

And I'd be, like,
no, it's tough.
He was right.

Fortunately, I've been able to
be successful at every step.

MOLLIE BREEN: I come
from a really big family,
and I have an identical twin.
She's my best friend.

I always thought of us as
two sides of the same coin.

So I was the long distance
runner, and she was a sprinter.

And when we both loved science,
I focused really on math
and she was on physics.

And I think that we did that
so that we were never competing
against each other directly.

JULIO CEDENO: I
definitely didn't

think that I was qualified
or able to get into HBS.

ERIN KAIVAN: I knew this
much, zero, about finance,
about accounting.

IGNACIO LARTIRIGOYEN:
Some people

make the assumption
that they won't get in
so they don't apply.

And I think that
is a big mistake.

MELCOLM RUFFIN: I would hope
that people don't discount

themselves by thinking
that, if they don't have

certain metrics, that
they're not able to attend
an institution like HBS.

ERIN KAIVAN: When I was in
the army, like, I think maybe

I just had the confidence
that, if I could do this, like,

I can do at least
the application
for Harvard Business School.

IGNACIO LARTIRIGOYEN:
The university

likes diverse backgrounds
and really appreciates
different experiences.
[SLOW MUSIC]
